content.body: given the matching semantic we're using (sameValue or sameValueZero, whatever), that gives the same results, right? `when ^null` will match `null` but not `undefined`, right?
content.formatted_body: given the matching semantic we're using (sameValue or sameValueZero, whatever), that gives the same results, right? when ^null will match null but not undefined, right?

content.body: `when ^null` will match `when (null)`, yes - only `null` - but `when ^undefined` will only match `when (undefined)` (ie, only `undefined`) when there's no shadowed `undefined` identifier set to "not `undefined`"
content.formatted_body: when ^null will match when (null), yes - only null - but when ^undefined will only match when (undefined) (ie, only undefined) when there's no shadowed undefined identifier set to "not undefined"

content.body: Right. `when ^undefined` is just doing a variable lookup for the name "undefined", which can theoretically be bound to whatever.
content.formatted_body: Right. when ^undefined is just doing a variable lookup for the name "undefined", which can theoretically be bound to whatever.

content.body: As that's the meaning of `undefined` in a normal expression context, which `^` provides.
content.formatted_body: As that's the meaning of undefined in a normal expression context, which ^ provides.
